form.longName: PhenX PX101701 - Sexual Risk Behavior Male
form.preferredDefinition: The purpose of this measure is to quantify sexual risk behavior in women or men. The measure quantifies both same-sex and opposite-sex interactions.

question.questionText: Have you ever had any kind of sex (sexual_risk_behavior_male_any_sex)
Have you ever had vaginal sex, also called sexual intercourse, with a woman? This means putting your penis in a woman's vagina. (sexual_risk_behavior_male_vaginal_sex)
Have you ever performed oral sex on a woman? This means putting your mouth on a woman's vagina or genitals. (sexual_risk_behavior_male_oral_sex)
Have you ever had anal sex with a woman? This means contact between your penis and a woman's anus or butt. (sexual_risk_behavior_male_anal_sex)

How old were you the first time you had any kind of sex, including {vaginal, anal, or oral/vaginal or anal/vaginal or oral/anal or oral/vaginal/anal/oral}? (sexual_risk_behavior_male_any_sex_first_time_age)

How old were you the first time you had any kind of sex, including {vaginal, anal, or oral/vaginal or anal/vaginal or oral/anal or oral/vaginal/anal/oral}? (sexual_risk_behavior_male_any_sex_first_time_age_encoded)
In your lifetime, with how many women have you had any kind of sex? (sexual_risk_behavior_male_any_sex_lifetime_women_number)
In your lifetime, with how many women have you had any kind of sex? (sexual_risk_behavior_male_any_sex_lifetime_women_number_encoded)
In the past 12 months, with how many women have you had any kind of sex? (sexual_risk_behavior_male_any_sex_past_year_women_number)
In the past 12 months, with how many women have you had any kind of sex? (sexual_risk_behavior_male_any_sex_past_year_women_number_encoded)
Have you ever had vaginal sex, also called sexual intercourse, with a woman? This means putting your penis in a woman’s vagina. (sexual_risk_behavior_male_vaginal_sex_lifetime_women_number)
In your lifetime, with how many women have you had vaginal sex? Vaginal sex means your penis in woman's vagina. (sexual_risk_behavior_male_vaginal_sex_lifetime_women_number_encoded)
In the past 12 months, with how many women have you had vaginal sex? Vaginal sex means your penis in a woman's vagina. (sexual_risk_behavior_male_vaginal_sex_past_year_women_number)
In the past 12 months, with how many women have you had vaginal sex? Vaginal sex means your penis in a woman's vagina. (sexual_risk_behavior_male_vaginal_sex_past_year_women_number_encoded)
In the past 12 months, about how often have you had [vaginal or anal/vaginal/anal] sex without using a condom? (sexual_risk_behavior_male_vaginal_anal_sex_past_year_without_condom_frequency)
Have you ever had any kind of sex with a man, including oral or anal? (sexual_risk_behavior_male_any_sex_man)
Have you ever performed oral sex on a man? Performing oral sex means your mouth on a man's penis or genitals. (sexual_risk_behavior_male_oral_sex_man)
In your lifetime, on how many men have you performed oral sex? (sexual_risk_behavior_male_oral_sex_lifetime_men_number)
In your lifetime, on how many men have you performed oral sex? (sexual_risk_behavior_male_oral_sex_lifetime_men_number_encoded)
In the past 12 months, with how many men have you had anal sex? (sexual_risk_behavior_male_anal_sex_past_year_men_number)
In the past 12 months, with how many men have you had anal sex? (sexual_risk_behavior_male_anal_sex_past_year_men_number_encoded)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The purpose of this measure is to quantify sexual risk behavior in women or men. The measure quantifies both same-sex and opposite-sex interactions.

form.longName: PhenX PX101702 - Sexual Risk Behavior Female

form.longName: PhenX PX121602 - Lack Of Prosocial Emotions Children Preschool Parent
form.preferredDefinition: The Inventory of Callous-Unemotional Traits (ICU) parent-report preschool version is a 24-item, self-administered questionnaire that includes three subscales: callousness, uncaring, and unemotional. Each item is rated on a 4-point Likert scale: 0 = not at all true; 1 = somewhat true; 2 = very true; 3 = definitely true. Items are added together to give a total score, with higher scores indicating a greater degree of callous-unemotional traits.

module.longName: Lack Of Prosocial Emotions Children Preschool Parent
module.preferredDefinition: Lack Of Prosocial Emotions Children Preschool Parent

question.questionText: How well does the student expresses his/her feelings openly. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_express_feelings)
The student does not seem to know "right" from "wrong". (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_right_wrong)
The student seems motivated to do his/her best in structured activities. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_care_school_work_)
The student does not care who he/she hurts to get what he/she wants. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_hurt)
The student feels bad or guilty when he/she has done something wrong. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_bad_guilt)
The student does not show emotions. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_show_emotions)
The student does not care about being on time. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_punctual)
The student is concerned about the feelings of others. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_concerned_others_feelings)
The student does not care if he/she is in trouble. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_trouble)
The student does not let feelings control him/her (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_feelings)
The student does not care about doing things well. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_careless)
The student seems very cold and uncaring. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_cold_uncaring_others)
The student easily admits to being wrong. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_admit_wrong)
It is easy to tell how he/she is feeling. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_easy_others_feelings)
The student always tries his/her best. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_try_best)
The student apologizes ("says he/she is sorry") to persons he/she has hurt. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_apologize)
The student tries not to hurt others' feelings. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_others_feelings_important)
The student shows no remorse when he/she has done something wrong. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_remorseful)
The student is very expressive and emotional. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_expressive_emotional)
The student does not like to put the time into doing things well. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_time_perform_well)
The feelings of others are unimportant to him/her. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_others_feelings_unimportant)
The student hides his/her feelings from others (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_hide_feelings)
The student works hard on everything. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_work_hard)
The student does things to make others feel good. (lack_prosocial_emotions_children_self_report_motivation_others_feelings)

form.longName: PhenX PX121701 - Depression Adult
form.preferredDefinition: The Quick Inventory of Depressive Symptoms (QIDS) is a self-administered questionnaire; QIDS includes 16 items that capture the severity of nine depressive symptoms in the last 7 days. Each item is rated on a 4-point scale (0-3); total scores range from 0-27, with higher scores indicating more severe depression.

question.questionText: What response best decribes you falling asleep over the past seven days? (depression_adult_falling_asleep)

validValue.meaningText: I never take longer than 30 minutes to fall asleep.
validValue.description: I never take longer than 30 minutes to fall asleep.

validValue.meaningText: I take at least 30 minutes to fall asleep, less than half the time.

validValue.meaningText: I do not wake up at night.
validValue.description: I do not wake up at night.

validValue.meaningText: I have a restless, light sleep with a few brief awakenings each night.
validValue.description: I have a restless, light sleep with a few brief awakenings each night.

validValue.meaningText: I wake up at least once a night, but I go back to sleep easily.
validValue.description: I wake up at least once a night, but I go back to sleep easily.

validValue.meaningText: I awaken more than once a night and stay awake for 20 minutes or more, more than half the time.
validValue.description: I awaken more than once a night and stay awake for 20 minutes or more, more than half the time.

question.questionText: What response best decribes you waking up too early over the past seven days? (depression_adult_waking_up)

validValue.meaningText: Most of the time, I awaken no more than 30 minutes before I need to get up.
validValue.description: Most of the time, I awaken no more than 30 minutes before I need to get up.

validValue.meaningText: More than half the time, I awaken more than 30 minutes before I need to get up.
validValue.description: More than half the time, I awaken more than 30 minutes before I need to get up.

validValue.meaningText: I almost always awaken at least one hour or so before I need to, but I go back to sleep eventually.
validValue.description: I almost always awaken at least one hour or so before I need to, but I go back to sleep eventually.

validValue.meaningText: I awaken at least one hour before I need to, and can't go back to sleep.
validValue.description: I awaken at least one hour before I need to, and can't go back to sleep.

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Quick Inventory of Depressive Symptoms (QIDS) is a self-administered questionnaire; QIDS includes 16 items that capture the severity of nine depressive symptoms in the last 7 days. Each item is rated on a 4-point scale (0-3); total scores range from 0-27, with higher scores indicating more severe depression.

form.longName: PhenX PX121704 - Depressive Symptoms - Geriatric
form.preferredDefinition: The Mood and Feelings Questionnaire (MFQ) is a 13-item, self-administered questionnaire on depressive symptoms. Each item is rated on a 3-point scale (0 = not true; 1 = sometimes true; 2 = true), and total scores range from 0-26, with higher scores indicating more severe depression symptoms.

question.questionText: During the past week have you felt satisfied with your life? (Depression_Symptoms_Geriatric_ Satisfied)
During the past week have you dropped many of your activities and interests? (Depression_Symptoms_Geriatric_ Dropped_Activities)
During the past week have you felt that your life is empty?? (Depression_Symptoms_Geriatric_Empty )
During the past week have you felt often bored? (Depression_Symptoms_Geriatric_ Bored)
During the past week have you felt in good spirits most of the time? (Depression_Symptoms_Geriatric_ Good_Spirits)
During the past week have you felt afraid that something bad is going to happen to you? (Depression_Symptoms_Geriatric_ Afraid)
During the past week have you felt happy most of the time? (Depression_Symptoms_Geriatric_ Happy)
During the past week have you often felt helpless? (Depression_Symptoms_Geriatric_ Helpless)
During the past week have you felt that you prefer to stay at home, rather than going out and doing new things? (Depression_Symptoms_Geriatric_ Stay_Home)
During the past week have you felt you have more problems with memory than most? (Depression_Symptoms_Geriatric_ Memory)
During the past week have you felt you think it is wonderful to be alive now? (Depression_Symptoms_Geriatric_ Alive)
During the past week have you felt pretty worthless the way you are now? (Depression_Symptoms_Geriatric_ Worthless)
During the past week have you felt full of energy? (Depression_Symptoms_Geriatric_ Energy)
During the past week have you felt that your situation is hopeless? (Depression_Symptoms_Geriatric_Hopeless)
During the past week have you felt you think that most people are better off than you are? (Depression_Symptoms_Geriatric_ Better_Off)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Mood and Feelings Questionnaire (MFQ) is a 13-item, self-administered questionnaire on depressive symptoms. Each item is rated on a 3-point scale (0 = not true; 1 = sometimes true; 2 = true), and total scores range from 0-26, with higher scores indicating more severe depression symptoms.

form.longName: PhenX PX130202 - Neuropathy Autonomic Assessment Adult
form.preferredDefinition: The Survey of Autonomic Symptoms (SAS) is a self-administered 12-item questionnaire that measures autonomic symptoms over the past 6 months in subjects with mild neuropathy. The severity of each item is rated on 5-point Likert scale (1 is least severe; 5 is most severe). The total number of symptoms is calculated as the sum of column A. The total impact score is calculated as the total of column B.

question.questionText: Have you had any of the following health symptoms during the past 6 months? Do you have lightheadedness? (autonomic_assessment_adult_lightheadedness)
If you answered yes in Q1a, how much would you say the symptom bothers you? (autonomic_assessment_adult_lightheadedness_symptoms_discomfort)
Have you had any of the following health symptoms during the past 6 months? Do you have a dry mouth or dry eyes? (autonomic_assessment_adult_dry_mouth_dry_eyes)
If you answered yes in Q2a, how much would you say the symptom bothers you? (autonomic_assessment_adult_dry_mouth_dry_eyes_symptoms_discomfort)
Have you had any of the following health symptoms during the past 6 months? Are your feet pale or blue? (autonomic_assessment_adult_feet_pale_blue)
If you answered yes in Q3a, how much would you say the symptom bothers you? (autonomic_assessment_adult_feet_pale_blue_symptoms_discomfort)
Have you had any of the following health symptoms during the past 6 months? Are your feet colder than the rest of your body? (autonomic_assessment_adult_feet_colder)
If you answered yes in Q4a, how much would you say the symptom bothers you? (autonomic_assessment_adult_feet_colder_symptoms_discomfort)
Have you had any of the following health symptoms during the past 6 months? Is sweating in your feet decreased compared to the rest of your body? (autonomic_assessment_adult_sweating_feet_decreased)
If you answered yes in Q5a, how much would you say the symptom bothers you? (autonomic_assessment_adult_sweating_feet_decreased_symptoms_discomfort)

Have you had any of the following health symptoms during the past 6 months? Is sweating in your feet decreased or absent (for example, after exercise or during hot weather)? (autonomic_assessment_adult_sweating_feet_decreased_absent_)
If you answered yes in Q6a, how much would you say the symptom bothers you? (autonomic_assessment_adult_sweating_feet_decreased_absent_symptoms_discomfort)

Have you had any of the following health symptoms during the past 6 months? Is sweating in your hands increased compared to the rest of your body? (autonomic_assessment_adult_sweating_hands_increased)
If you answered yes in Q7a, how much would you say the symptom bothers you? (autonomic_assessment_adult_sweating_hands_increased_symptoms_discomfort)

Have you had any of the following health symptoms during the past 6 months? Do you have nausea, vomiting, or bloating after eating a small meal? (autonomic_assessment_adult_nausea_vomiting_bloating_small_meal)
If you answered yes in Q8a, how much would you say the symptom bothers you? (autonomic_assessment_adult_nausea_vomiting_bloating_small_meal_symptoms_discomfort)

Have you had any of the following health symptoms during the past 6 months? Do you have persistent diarrhea (more than 3 loose bowel movements per day)? (autonomic_assessment_adult_persistent_diarrhea)
If you answered yes in Q9a, how much would you say the symptom bothers you? (autonomic_assessment_adult_persistent_diarrhea_symptoms_discomfort)

Have you had any of the following health symptoms during the past 6 months? Do you have persistent constipation (less than 1 bowel movement every other day)? (autonomic_assessment_adult_persistent_constipation)
If you answered yes in Q10a, how much would you say the symptom bothers you? (autonomic_assessment_adult_persistent_constipation_symptoms_discomfort)
Have you had any of the following health symptoms during the past 6 months? Do you have leaking of urine? (autonomic_assessment_adult_leaking_urine)
If you answered yes in Q11a, how much would you say the symptom bothers you? (autonomic_assessment_adult_leaking_urine_symptoms_discomfort)
Have you had any of the following health symptoms during the past 6 months? Do you have difficulty obtaining an erection (men)? (autonomic_assessment_adult_difficulty_obtaining_erection_)
If you answered yes in Q12a, how much would you say the symptom bothers you? (autonomic_assessment_adult_difficulty_obtaining_erection_symptoms_discomfort)

form.longName: PhenX PX180302 - Quality Of Life Enjoyment And Satisfaction Adults
form.preferredDefinition: The Quality of Life Enjoyment and Satisfaction Questionnaire - Short Form (Q-LES-Q-SF) is a 16 item self-administered questionnaire that captures life satisfaction over the past week. Each question is rated on a 5 point scale from 1 (Very Poor) to 5 (Very Good). Scores from the individual items are added together and reported as percentage maximum possible score. The short-form of the Q-LES-Q-SF is identical to the General Activities subscale of the larger Quality of Life Enjoyment and Satisfaction Questionnaire (Q-LES-Q) instrument

form.longName: PhenX PX211402 - Race Ethnic Residential Segregation Us Census
form.preferredDefinition: The protocol is based on extracting data from the U.S. Census Bureau on a set of variables related to the concept of residential segregation. Residential segregation describes the distribution of different race/ethnic groups across smaller areal units (e.g., census tracts) within larger areas (e.g., counties or metropolitan statistical areas [MSAs]). The Dissimilarity Index is one of the most commonly used race/ethnic residential segregation measures. All the relevant variables are available from the decennial censuses or the American Community Survey (ACS) 5-year estimates. Once the data are extracted the proposed measure, the Dissimilarity Index can be calculated. Which data set should be used?Users interested in using measures of residential segregation in conjunction with the Neighborhood Concentrated Disadvantage protocol should use data from the ACS 5-year estimates for consistency of data sources. Users who are interested in using the 100% count data rather than estimates, or making comparisons of residential segregation in metropolitan areas across time (e.g. 1990 vs. 2010) should use data from the decennial censuses. The protocol here describes how to use Summary File 1 (SF1) files (i.e., 100% sample data) from the decennial censuses to calculate the Dissimilarity Index. Users interested in using the ACS data should refer to the other protocol for this measure.

protocol.longName: Race/Ethnic Residential Segregation - American Community Survey
protocol.preferredDefinition: The protocol is based on extracting data from the U.S. Census Bureau on a set of variables related to the concept of residential segregation. Residential segregation describes the distribution of different race/ethnic groups across smaller areal units (e.g., census tracts) within larger areas (e.g., counties or metropolitan statistical areas [MSAs]). The Dissimilarity Index is one of the most commonly used race/ethnic residential segregation measures. All the relevant variables are available from the decennial censuses or the American Community Survey (ACS) 5-year estimates. Once the data are extracted, the Dissimilarity Index can be calculated. Which data set should be used?Users interested in using measures of residential segregation in conjunction with the Neighborhood Concentrated Disadvantage protocol should use data from the ACS 5-year estimates for consistency of data sources. Users who are interested in using the 100% count data rather than estimates or making comparisons of residential segregation in metropolitan areas across time (e.g., 1990 vs. 2010) should use data from the Decennial Censuses. The protocol here describes the process using 5-year estimates from the ACS. Users interested in using the Decennial Census data should refer to the alternate protocol.\r\n

form.longName: PhenX PX240301 - Concentrations Of Phenols And Parabens
form.preferredDefinition: Urine is collected from the subject in a pre-screened 120 ml urine container and then placed in a refrigerator or on ice packs immediately after collection. Transfer to polypropylene vial. Transport or ship urine samples on dry ice. Place urine samples in a -70° C freezer and store until shipment or analysis.Thaw sample, and perform analysis via on-line solid phase extraction-high performance liquid chromatography-isotope dilution-tandem mass spectrometry (SPE-HPLC-isotope dilution-MS/MS).

validValue.meaningText: IVF (in vitro fertilization). Fertilization takes place in a Petri dish and the embryo transferred to the uterus.
validValue.description: IVF (in vitro fertilization). Fertilization takes place in a Petri dish and the embryo transferred to the uterus.

validValue.meaningText: IVF+ assisted hatching. Same as 1 except the layer of cells covering the egg (zona pellucida) is removed permitting easier and earlier cell division in the embryo.
validValue.description: IVF+ assisted hatching. Same as 1 except the layer of cells covering the egg (zona pellucida) is removed permitting easier and earlier cell division in the embryo.

validValue.meaningText: GIFT (gamete intra fallopian transfer). Sperm and egg are injected into the fallopian tube where fertilization takes place.
validValue.description: GIFT (gamete intra fallopian transfer). Sperm and egg are injected into the fallopian tube where fertilization takes place.

validValue.meaningText: ZIFT (zygote intra fallopian transfer). Fertilization takes place in a Petri dish and the embryo transferred to the fallopian tube.
validValue.description: ZIFT (zygote intra fallopian transfer). Fertilization takes place in a Petri dish and the embryo transferred to the fallopian tube.

validValue.meaningText: ICSI (intra cytoplasmic sperm injection). Sperm are injected into the cytoplasm of the egg and the resulting embryo transferred to the uterus.
validValue.description: ICSI (intra cytoplasmic sperm injection). Sperm are injected into the cytoplasm of the egg and the resulting embryo transferred to the uterus.

validValue.meaningText: ICSI + assisted hatching. Same as 5 except the zona pellucida is removed.
validValue.description: ICSI + assisted hatching. Same as 5 except the zona pellucida is removed.

form.longName: PhenX PX520406 - Expectancies Alcohol
form.preferredDefinition: The Brief Comprehensive Effects of Alcohol questionnaire (B-CEOA) is a 15-item version of the Comprehensive Effects of Alcohol Questionnaire (CEOA). The CEOA uses 38 items consisting of 7 factors - 4 positive (Sociability, Tension Reduction, Liquid Courage, and Sexuality) and 3 negative (Cognitive and Behavioral Impairment, Risk and Aggression, and Self-Perception) - for assessing expectancies concerning alcohol effects. Respondents indicate their degree of agreement that a particular effect will likely occur if they drink, using a 1-4 scale (1 = disagree, 4 = agree).The B-CEOA uses 15 items, including 2 items from each of the 7 expectancy scales, except for the Risk and Aggression scale, which contains 3 items.

form.longName: PhenX PX550302 - Perceived Availability Of Illegal Drugs And Alcohol
form.preferredDefinition: The Monitoring the Future (MTF) project studies changes in the beliefs, attitudes, and behavior of young people in the United States. The MTF is a repeated series of surveys in which the same segments of the population (8th-, 10th-, and 12th-graders; college students; and young adults) are presented with the same set of questions over a period of years to see how answers change over time. Respondents complete self-administered questionnaires.

headerInstruction.text: How difficult do you think it would be for you to get the following drug if you wanted some? (Mark one circle)

form.longName: PhenX PX660601 - Creactive Protein Crp
form.preferredDefinition: This protocol includes recommended technical and analytical procedures for the consistent quantification of C-reactive protein (CRP) from serum. These procedures include the application of mouse monoclonal anti-CRP antibody-bound polystyrene particles to a diluted serum sample. CRP in the sample forms an antigen-antibody complex with the latex particles that are then quantified by measuring light scatter in a nephelometer. CRP concentrations are calculated using a calibration curve.

question.questionText: If testing is not performed within 24 hours of collection, are specimens stored at -20 degrees Celsius or cooler? (creactive_protein_specimen_handling)
Was the serum or plasma separated from the collected blood within 60 minutes of collection? (creactive_protein_blood_collection)
Is the sample volume at least 0.3 mL? (creactive_protein_sample_volume_minimum)
Are the specimens stored in glass or plastic vials? (creactive_protein_sample_storage)
Were lipemic specimens clarified by centrifugation for 10 minutes at about 15,000g prior to testing? (creactive_protein_lipemic_specimens)
Were the CardioPhase, Rheumatology, and Supplementary reagents stored between 4-8 degrees Celsius and never frozen? (creactive_protein_cardiophase_rheumatology_reagent)
Were the Diluent and Rx buffer reagents stored at room temperature? (creactive_protein_diluent_rx_buffer)
Were the quality control materials stored at -20 degrees Celsius or colder before being thawed and stored at 2-8 degrees Celsius and used within 30 days? (creactive_protein_quality_control)
Were the calibration standard dilutions used within 4 hours of preparation? (creactive_protein_calibration_standard_dilutions)
Did any of the three levels of control run for each test series not conform to specificatoins as defined in the quality control manual? (creactive_protein_quality_control_series)
Were the temperatures of the controls and patient specimens brought up to room temperature before use? (creactive_protein_controls_specimens_mixing)
Are the dilution wells empty? (creactive_protein_dilution_wells)
Were bench quality control specimens used at the beginning of each analystical run? (creactive_protein_bench_quality_control)
Is the lowest reportable value at least 0.02 mg/dL? (creactive_protein_lower_limit_assay)
Were specimens maintained at 20-25 degrees Celsius during tesing and stored at -70 degrees Celsius or lower after testing? (creactive_protein_specimen_handling_testing)

protocol.preferredDefinition: This protocol includes recommended technical and analytical procedures for the consistent quantification of C-reactive protein (CRP) from serum. These procedures include the application of mouse monoclonal anti-CRP antibody-bound polystyrene particles to a diluted serum sample. CRP in the sample forms an antigen-antibody complex with the latex particles that are then quantified by measuring light scatter in a nephelometer. CRP concentrations are calculated using a calibration curve.

form.longName: PhenX PX661101 - Psychosis Recovery Assessment
form.preferredDefinition: The Questionnaire about the Process of Recovery (QPR) is a 15-item, self-administered rating scale that captures a patient's viewpoint about recovery from psychosis. The QPR should be completed in proximity to another professional or person to discuss any questions or issues. Each item is rated on a 5-point scale (0 = disagree strongly, 1 = disagree, 2 = neither agree nor disagree, 3 = agree, 4 = agree strongly), and items are added together to give a total recovery score, with higher scores indicating greater recovery.

question.questionText: I feel better about myself (processof_recovery_feel_better)
I feel able to take chances in life (processof_recovery_take_chances)
I am able to develop positive relationships with other people (processof_recovery_relationships)
I feel part of society rather than isolated (processof_recovery_societal_worth)
I am able to assert myself (processof_recovery_assertive)
I feel that my life has a purpose (processof_recovery_life_purpose)
My experiences have changed me for the better (processof_recovery_experiences)
I have been able to come to terms with things that have happened to me in the past and move on with my life (processof_recovery_past)
I am basically strongly motivated to get better (processof_recovery_motivated)
I can recognise the positive things I have done (processof_recovery_positive)
I am able to understand myself better (processof_recovery_understand)
I can take charge of my life (processof_recovery_charge)
I can actively engage with life (processof_recovery_engage_life)
I can take control of aspects of my life (processof_recovery_control)
I can find the time to do the things I enjoy (processof_recovery_time)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Questionnaire about the Process of Recovery (QPR) is a 15-item, self-administered rating scale that captures a patient's viewpoint about recovery from psychosis. The QPR should be completed in proximity to another professional or person to discuss any questions or issues. Each item is rated on a 5-point scale (0 = disagree strongly, 1 = disagree, 2 = neither agree nor disagree, 3 = agree, 4 = agree strongly), and items are added together to give a total recovery score, with higher scores indicating greater recovery.

form.longName: PhenX PX661401 - Mental Health Services Satisfaction
form.preferredDefinition: The Mental Health Statics Improvement Program (MHSIP) Youth Services Survey (YSS) is a 25-item, self-administered rating scale that captures a patient's viewpoint about service satisfaction. The YSS should be completed in proximity to another professional or person to discuss any questions or issues. Each item is rated on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree, 2 = Disagree, 3 = Undecided, Agree = 4, Strongly Agree = 5). Ratings from the individual items can be added together to yield a total score, with higher scores indicating greater satisfaction.

question.questionText: Overall, I am satisfied with the services I received. (mentalhealth_service_survey_overall)
I helped to choose my services. (mentalhealth_service_survey_choose_service)
I helped to choose my treatment goals. (mentalhealth_service_survey_choose_goals)
The people helping me stuck with me no matter what. (mentalhealth_service_survey_support_system)
I felt I had someone to talk to when I was troubled. (mentalhealth_service_survey_support)
I participated in my own treatment. (mentalhealth_service_survey_participation)
I received services that were right for me. (mentalhealth_service_survey_treatment)
The location of services was convenient. (mentalhealth_service_survey_location)
Services were available at times that were convenient for me. (mentalhealth_service_survey_convenience)
I got the help I wanted. (mentalhealth_service_survey_desired_help)
I got as much help as I needed. (mentalhealth_service_survey_limitations)
Staff treated me with respect. (mentalhealth_service_survey_respect)
Staff respected my family’s religious/spiritual beliefs. (mentalhealth_service_survey_beliefs)
Staff spoke with me in a way that I understood. (mentalhealth_service_survey_communication)
Staff were sensitive to my cultural/ethnic background. (mentalhealth_service_survey_sensitivity)
As a result of the services I received, I am better at handling daily life. (mentalhealth_service_survey_daily_life)
As a result of the services I received, I get along better with family members. (mentalhealth_service_survey_family)
As a result of the services I received, I get along better with friends and other people. (mentalhealth_service_survey_friends)
As a result of the services I received, I am doing better in school and/or work. (mentalhealth_service_survey_work_school)
As a result of the services I received, I am better able to cope when things go wrong. (mentalhealth_service_survey_coping_skills)
As a result of the services I received, I am satisfied with my family life right now. (mentalhealth_service_survey_family_life)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Mental Health Statics Improvement Program (MHSIP) Youth Services Survey (YSS) is a 25-item, self-administered rating scale that captures a patient's viewpoint about service satisfaction. The YSS should be completed in proximity to another professional or person to discuss any questions or issues. Each item is rated on a 5-point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree, 2 = Disagree, 3 = Undecided, Agree = 4, Strongly Agree = 5). Ratings from the individual items can be added together to yield a total score, with higher scores indicating greater satisfaction.

form.longName: PhenX PX661901 - Physical Activity
form.preferredDefinition: The International Physical Activity Questionnaire (IPAQ) is a 7-item, self-administered questionnaire that captures a subject's physical activity over the last 7 days.

question.questionText: During the last 7 days, on how many days did you do vigorous physical activities like heavy lifting, digging, aerobics, or fast bicycling? (physical_activity_questionnaire_vigorous)
How much time did you usually spend doing vigorous physical activities on one of those days? (physical_activity_questionnaire_vigorous_hours)
How much time did you usually spend doing vigorous physical activities on one of those days? (physical_activity_questionnaire_vigorous_minutes)
How much time did you usually spend doing vigorous physical activities on one of those days? (physical_activity_questionnaire_vigorous_other)

Think about all the moderate activities that you did in the last 7 days. Moderate activities refer to activities that take moderate physical effort and make you breathe somewhat harder than normal. Think only about those physical activities that you did for at least 10 minutes at a time. During the last 7 days, on how many days did you do moderate physical activities like carrying light loads, bicycling at a regular pace, or doubles tennis? Do not include walking. (physical_activity_questionnaire_moderate)
How much time did you usually spend doing moderate physical activities on one of those days? (physical_activity_questionnaire_moderate_hours)
How much time did you usually spend doing moderate physical activities on one of those days? (physical_activity_questionnaire_moderate_minutes)
How much time did you usually spend doing moderate physical activities on one of those days? (physical_activity_questionnaire_moderate_other)

Think about the time you spent walking in the last 7 days. This includes at work and at home, walking to travel from place to place, and any other walking that you have done solely for recreation, sport, exercise, or leisure. During the last 7 days, on how many days did you walk for at least 10 minutes at a time? (physical_activity_questionnaire_walking)
How much time did you usually spend walking on one of those days? (physical_activity_questionnaire_walking_hours)
How much time did you usually spend walking on one of those days? (physical_activity_questionnaire_walking_minutes)
How much time did you usually spend walking on one of those days? (physical_activity_questionnaire_walking_other)

The last question is about the time you spent sitting on weekdays during the last 7 days. Include time spent at work, at home, while doing course work and during leisure time. This may include time spent sitting at a desk, visiting friends, reading, or sitting or lying down to watch television. During the last 7 days, how much time did you spend sitting on a week day? (physical_activity_questionnaire_sitting_hours)

The last question is about the time you spent sitting on weekdays during the last 7 days. Include time spent at work, at home, while doing course work and during leisure time. This may include time spent sitting at a desk, visiting friends, reading, or sitting or lying down to watch television. During the last 7 days, how much time did you spend sitting on a week day? (physical_activity_questionnaire_sitting_minutes)

The last question is about the time you spent sitting on weekdays during the last 7 days. Include time spent at work, at home, while doing course work and during leisure time. This may include time spent sitting at a desk, visiting friends, reading, or sitting or lying down to watch television. During the last 7 days, how much time did you spend sitting on a week day? (physical_activity_questionnaire_sitting_other)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The International Physical Activity Questionnaire (IPAQ) is a 7-item, self-administered questionnaire that captures a subject's physical activity over the last 7 days.

form.longName: PhenX PX662001 - Family Expressed Emotion Toward Relatives With Psychosis
form.preferredDefinition: The Family Questionnaire (FQ) is a 20-item, self-administered questionnaire that measures expressed emotion status (criticism and emotional over involvement [EOI]) of family members toward patients with mental illness. The FQ has two subscales: critical comments, and EOI. Each item is rated on a 4-point scale (1 = never/very rarely; 4 = very often). The FQ is scored by adding together the ratings from the individual items, with higher scores indicating greater levels of expressed emotion.

module.longName: Family Expressed Emotion Toward Relatives With Psychosis
module.preferredDefinition: Family Expressed Emotion Toward Relatives With Psychosis

question.questionText: I tend to neglect myself because of him or her (family_questionnaire_neglect)
I have to keep asking him or her to do things (family_questionnaire_manage)
I often think about what is to become of him or her (family_questionnaire_future)
He or she irritates me (family_questionnaire_irritating)
I keep thinking about the reasons for his or her illness (family_questionnaire_reason_illness)
I have to try not to criticize him or her (family_questionnaire_criticism)
I can't sleep because of him or her (family_questionnaire_difficulty_sleeping)
It's hard for us to agree on things (family_questionnaire_difficulty_agreeing)
When something about him or her bothers me, I keep it to myself (family_questionnaire_internalization)
He or she does not appreciate what I do for him or her (family_questionnaire_appreciative)
I regard my own needs as less important (family_questionnaire_sacrifice_needs)
He or she sometimes gets on my nerves (family_questionnaire_annoyed)
I'm very worried about him or her (family_questionnaire_worried)
He or she does some things out of spite (family_questionnaire_spite)
I thought I would become ill myself (family_questionnaire_illness)
When he or she constantly wants something from me, it annoys me (family_questionnaire_needy)
He or she is an important part of my life (family_questionnaire_important)
I have to insist that he or she behave differently (family_questionnaire_behavior)
I have given up important things in order to be able to help him or her (family_questionnaire_sacrifice)
I'm often angry with him or her (family_questionnaire_anger)

protocol.longName: Family Expressed Emotion Toward Relatives with Psychosis and Schizophrenia
protocol.preferredDefinition: The Family Questionnaire (FQ) is a 20-item, self-administered questionnaire that measures expressed emotion status (criticism and emotional over involvement [EOI]) of family members toward patients with mental illness. The FQ has two subscales: critical comments, and EOI. Each item is rated on a 4-point scale (1 = never/very rarely; 4 = very often). The FQ is scored by adding together the ratings from the individual items, with higher scores indicating greater levels of expressed emotion.

form.longName: PhenX PX662102 - Family Functioning Systematic Clinical Outcome Routine
form.preferredDefinition: The 15-item Systematic Clinical Outcome Routine Evaluation (SCORE-15) Index of Family Functioning and Change is a 15-item, self-administered instrument that assesses family problems and includes subscales for family strengths, family difficulties, and family communication. Each item is rated on a 5-point scale where 1 = Describes us: Very well and 5 = Describes us: Not at all. The scores from all individual items can be added together into a total family problem score. Subscale scores are derived by adding the questions for each of the dimensions: Strengths and Adaptability (questions 1, 3, 6, 10, 15); Overwhelmed by Difficulties dimension (questions 5, 7, 9, 11, 14); and Disrupted Communication dimension (questions 2, 4, 8, 12, 13).

module.longName: Family Functioning Systematic Clinical Outcome Routine
module.preferredDefinition: Family Functioning Systematic Clinical Outcome Routine

question.questionText: In my family we talk to each other about things which matter to us (score_family_functioning_discussion)
People often don't tell each other the truth in my family (score_family_functioning_truthfulness)
Each of us gets listened to in our family (score_family_functioning_respect)
It feels risky to disagree in our family (score_family_functioning_disagreement)
We find it hard to deal with everyday problems (score_family_functioning_everyday_problems)
We trust each other (score_family_functioning_trust)
It feels miserable in our family (score_family_functioning_miserable)
When people in my family get angry they ignore each other on purpose (score_family_functioning_anger)
We seem to go from one crisis to another in my family (score_family_functioning_crisis)
When one of us is upset they get looked after within the family (score_family_functioning_upset)
Things always seem to go wrong for my family (score_family_functioning_chaos)
People in the family are nasty to each other (score_family_functioning_nasty)
People in my family interfere too much in each other's lives (score_family_functioning_interference)
In my family we blame each other when things go wrong (score_family_functioning_blame)
We are good at finding new ways to deal with things that are difficult (score_family_functioning_difficult_situations)

protocol.longName: Family Functioning - Systematic Clinical Outcome Routine Evaluation
protocol.preferredDefinition: The 15-item Systematic Clinical Outcome Routine Evaluation (SCORE-15) Index of Family Functioning and Change is a 15-item, self-administered instrument that assesses family problems and includes subscales for family strengths, family difficulties, and family communication. Each item is rated on a 5-point scale where 1 = Describes us: Very well and 5 = Describes us: Not at all. The scores from all individual items can be added together into a total family problem score. Subscale scores are derived by adding the questions for each of the dimensions: Strengths and Adaptability (questions 1, 3, 6, 10, 15); Overwhelmed by Difficulties dimension (questions 5, 7, 9, 11, 14); and Disrupted Communication dimension (questions 2, 4, 8, 12, 13).

form.longName: PhenX PX662201 - Family Burden Of Mental Illness
form.preferredDefinition: The Burden Assessment Scale (BAS) is a 19-item, self-administered scale to assess the burden on families with a seriously mentally ill family member. Items 1-10 assess objective consequences, including financial problems, limitations on personal activity, and household disruptions. Items 11-19 measure subjective consequences, including shame, stigma, guilt, and resentment. Each item is rated on a 4-point scale (1 = not at all; 4 = a lot). To score the BAS, ratings from each item are added together to give a total score, with higher scores indicating greater levels of caregiver burden.

question.questionText: Because of name's illness, to what extent have you: had financial problems (burden_assessment_financial_problems)
Because of name's illness, to what extent have you: missed days at work (or school) (burden_assessment_missed_work)
Because of name's illness, to what extent have you: found it difficult to concentrate on your own activities (burden_assessment_difficulty_concentrating)
Because of name's illness, to what extent have you: had to change your personal plans like taking a new job, or going on vacation (burden_assessment_change_personal_plans)
Because of name's illness, to what extent have you: cut down on leisure time (burden_assessment_less_leisure)
Because of name's illness, to what extent have you: found the household routine was upset (burden_assessment_routine_upsetting)
Because of name's illness, to what extent have you: had less time to spend with friends (burden_assessment_less_social)
Because of name's illness, to what extent have you: neglected other family members' needs (burden_assessment_neglected_others)
Because of name's illness, to what extent have you: experienced family frictions and arguments (burden_assessment_family_tensions)
Because of name's illness, to what extent have you: experienced frictions with neighbors, friends, or relatives outside the home (burden_assessment_tension_others)
Because of name's illness, to what extent have you: became embarrassed because of (name's) behavior (burden_assessment_embarrassed_behavior)
Because of name's illness, to what extent have you: felt guilty because you were not doing enough to help (burden_assessment_guilty_help)
Because of name's illness, to what extent have you: felt guilty because you felt responsible for causing (name's) problem (burden_assessment_guilty_problem)
Because of name's illness, to what extent have you: resented (name) because s or he made too many demands on you (burden_assessment_resentment)
Because of name's illness, to what extent have you: felt trapped by your caregiving role (burden_assessment_trapped)
Because of name's illness, to what extent have you: were upset about how much (name) had changed from his or her former self (burden_assessment_upset)
Because of name's illness, to what extent have you: worried about how your behavior with (name) might make the illness worse (burden_assessment_behavior_worsen_illness)
Because of name's illness, to what extent have you: worried about what the future holds for (name) (burden_assessment_future)
Because of name's illness, to what extent have you: found the stigma of the illness upsetting (burden_assessment_stigma_illness)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Burden Assessment Scale (BAS) is a 19-item, self-administered scale to assess the burden on families with a seriously mentally ill family member. Items 1-10 assess objective consequences, including financial problems, limitations on personal activity, and household disruptions. Items 11-19 measure subjective consequences, including shame, stigma, guilt, and resentment. Each item is rated on a 4-point scale (1 = not at all; 4 = a lot). To score the BAS, ratings from each item are added together to give a total score, with higher scores indicating greater levels of caregiver burden.
